standard_metadata.standard_description: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

question.content: Three divers kept track of the number of crabs they've seen this year.   Diver | Crabs observed | Dives - | :-: | :-: Scuba Sam | $33$ | $11$ Wet Suit Willy | $81$  | $18$ Deep Diving Dan | $104$ | $26$  **Which diver saw the most crabs per dive?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of crabs seen per $1$ dive.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{crabs}}}{\maroonD{\text{dives}}} = \purpleD{\text{crabs per dive}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want.  Diver| $\blueE{\text{Crabs}}$ ||  $\maroonD{\text{Dives}}$||$\purpleE{\text{Crabs per dive}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Scuba Sam |$33$|$\div$ | $11$|$=$|$3$ Wet Suit Willy|$81$ |$\div$ |$18$ | $=$|$4.5$ Deep Diving Dan |$104$ |$\div$ | $26$|$=$| $4 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Diver | Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Scuba Sam | $3$ | $.$ | $0$ Wet Suit Willy| $\redE{4}$ | $.$ | $\redE{5}$ Deep Diving Dan | $\redE{4}$ | $.$ | $0$  Wet Suit Willy and Deep Diving Dan both saw $4$ ones of crabs per dive, but between those two, Wet Suit Willy saw the most tenths of crabs per dive.
###Conclusion  Wet Suit Willy saw the most crabs per dive.

question.content: The price per night for a hotel room is different at three different hotels.   Hotel | Nights | Price (in dollars) - | :-: | :-: $A$ | $3$ | $192$ $B$ | $5$ | $300$ $C$ | $7$ | $455$  **Which hotel costs the least per night?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the price per $1$ night.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{total price}}}{\maroonD{\text{nights}}} = \purpleD{\text{price per night}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want, not the order of the columns in the original table.  Hotel| $\blueE{\text{Price}} $ || $\maroonD{\text{Nights}}$||$\purpleE{\text{Price per night}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$ |$192$|$\div$ | $3$|$=$|$64$ $B$|$300$ |$\div$ |$5$ | $=$|$60$ $C$ |$455$ |$\div$ | $7$|$=$| $65 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Hotel | Tens | Ones - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$ | $6$ | $4$ $B$| $6$ | $\redE{0}$ $C$ | $6$ | $5$  The hotels all cost $6$ tens of dollars per night, but hotel B costs the least ones of dollars per night.
###Conclusion  Hotel $B$ costs the least per night.

question.content: Three employees each clocked a different number of hours worked this week.  Employee | Total earnings (in dollars) | Hours of work - | :-: | :-: $A$ | $180$ | $15$ $B$ | $210$ | $20$ $C$ | $455$ | $35$  **Which employee has the highest earnings per hour?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the earnings, in dollars, per $1$ hour of work.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{total earnings}}}{\maroonD{\text{hours}}} = \purpleD{\text{earnings per hour}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want.  Employee| $\blueE{\text{Total earnings}} $ || $\maroonD{\text{Hours of}}$ $\maroonD{\text{work}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Earnings}}$ $\purpleE{\text{per hour}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$ |$180$|$\div$ | $15$|$=$|$12$ $B$|$210$ |$\div$ |$20$ | $=$|$10.5$ $C$ |$455$ |$\div$ | $35$|$=$| $13 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Employee | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-:  $A$ | $1$ | $2$ | $.$ | $0$ $B$| $1$ | $0$ | $.$ | $5$ $C$ | $1$ | $\redE{3}$ | $.$ | $0$  The employees all earn $1$ ten of dollars per hour, but employee C earns the most ones of dollars per hour.
###Conclusion  Employee $C$ has the highest earnings per hour.

question.content: There are three car salespeople at the local car dealership. The table below shows how many cars each salesperson has sold.  Car salesperson | Years of employment | Cars sold  - | :-: | :-: Ronaldo|$2$ | $104$ Maria |$7$ | $322$  Bruno | $12$  | $516$   **Which car salesperson sold the most cars per year?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of cars sold per $1$ year.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{cars}}}{\maroonD{\text{years}}} = \purpleD{\text{cars per year}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want, not the order of the columns in the original table.  Car salesperson| $\blueE{\text{Cars sold}}$ || $\maroonD{\text{Years of}}$ $\maroonD{\text{employment}}$|| $\purpleE{\text{Cars sold}}$ $\purpleE{\text{per year}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Ronaldo |$104$|$\div$ | $2$|$=$|$52$ Maria|$322$ |$\div$ |$7$ | $=$|$46$ Bruno |$516$ |$\div$ | $12$|$=$| $43$
###Comparing the unit rates  Car salesperson | Tens | Ones - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Ronaldo | $\redE{5}$ | $2$ Maria| $4$ | $6$ Bruno | $4$ | $3$  Ronaldo sold the most tens of cars per year.
###Conclusion  Ronaldo sold the most cars per year.

question.content: The table below shows the details of three different river rafting adventures.  Adventure | Duration (in hours) | Distance $(\text{km})$ - | :-: | :-: High Tide | $1$ | $3$ Monsoon | $2$ | $5$  Tsunami | $4$ | $14$  **Which river rafting adventure offers the lowest average speed in kilometers per hour?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the distance, in kilometers, per $1$ hour.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{distance}}}{\maroonD{\text{hours}}} = \purpleD{\text{km per hour}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want, not the order of the columns in the original table.  Adventure| $\blueE{\text{Distance}}$ || $\maroonD{\text{Duration}}$||$\purpleE{\text{Average speed}}$ $(\text{km/h})$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: High Tide |$3$|$\div$ | $1$|$=$|$3$ Monsoon|$5$ |$\div$ |$2$ | $=$|$2.5$ Tsunami |$14$ |$\div$ | $4$|$=$| $3.5$

###Comparing the unit rates  Adventure | Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: High Tide | $3$ | $.$ | $0$ Monsoon| $\redE{2}$ | $.$ | $5$ Tsunami |  $3$ | $.$ | $5$  The Monsoon adventure travels the fewest ones of kilometers per hour.
###Conclusion  Monsoon offers the lowest average speed.

question.content: There are three apple orchards. Each orchard has a different number of trees and apples.  Orchard |Apple trees | Total apples - | :-: | :-: The  #1 Seed  | $84$ | $38{,}614$ Sweet and Sour | $78$ | $33{,}088$ Apple Valley | $92$ | $39{,}873$  **Which orchard has the highest rate of *apples per tree*?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of apples per $1$ tree.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{apples}}}{\maroonD{\text{trees}}} = \purpleD{\text{apples per tree}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want, not the order of the columns in the original table.  Orchard| $\blueE{\text{Total apples}}$  ||  $\maroonD{\text{Apple trees}}$ || $\purpleD{\text{Apples per tree}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-:  The #1 Seed |$38{,}614$|$\div$ | $84$|$\approx$|$460$ Sweet and Sour|$33{,}088$ |$\div$ |$78$ | $\approx$|$424$ Apple Valley |$39{,}873$ |$\div$ | $92$|$\approx$| $433$

###Comparing the unit rates  Orchard | Hundreds | Tens | Ones - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-:  The #1 Seed | $4$ | $\redE{6}$ | $0$ Sweet and Sour| $4$ | $2$ | $4$ Apple Valley | $4$ | $3$ | $3$  The orchards all have $4$ hundreds of apples per tree, but the #1 Seed has the most tens of apples per tree.
###Conclusion  The #1 Seed has the highest rate of apples per tree.

question.content: Three different golfers played a different number of holes today. Shanika played $9$ holes and had a total of $43$ strokes. Alicia played $18$ holes and had a total of $79$ strokes.  Rickie played $27$ holes and had a total of $123$ strokes.  **Which golfer had the lowest *number of strokes per hole*?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of strokes per $1$ hole.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{strokes}}}{\maroonD{\text{holes}}} = \purpleD{\text{strokes per hole}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want.  Golfer| $\blueE{\text{Total strokes}} $ ||  $\maroonD{\text{Holes played}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Strokes per hole}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Shanika |$43$|$\div$ | $9$|$\approx$|$4.8$ Alicia|$79$ |$\div$ |$18$ | $\approx$|$4.4$ Rickie|$123$ |$\div$ | $27$|$\approx$| $4.6 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Golfer| Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Shanika | $4$ | $.$ | $8$ Alicia| $4$ | $.$ | $\redE{4}$ Rickie| $4$ | $.$ | $6$  The golfers all have $4$ ones of strokes per hole, but Alicia has the least tenths of strokes per hole.
###Conclusion  Alicia had the lowest number of strokes per hole.

question.content: A baseball team has three different pitchers. Randy allowed $2$ runs and pitched $3$ innings. Felix allowed $4$ runs and pitched $5$ innings. Johan allowed $5$ runs and pitched $7$ innings.   **Which pitcher has the lowest *number of runs allowed per inning*?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of runs allowed per $1$ inning.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{runs}}}{\maroonD{\text{innings}}} = \purpleD{\text{runs per inning}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want.  Pitcher| $\blueE{\text{Runs allowed}} $ || $\maroonD{\text{Innings pitched}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Runs per inning}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Randy|$2$|$\div$ | $3$|$\approx$|$0.67$ Felix|$4$ |$\div$ |$5$ | $=$|$0.8$ Johan |$5$ |$\div$ | $7$|$\approx$| $0.71 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Pitcher | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Randy| $0$ | $.$ | $\redE{6}$ | $7$ Felix| $0$ | $.$ | $8$ | $0$ Johan | $0$ | $.$ | $7$ | $1$  The pitchers all have $0$ ones of runs per inning, but Randy has the least tenths of runs per inning.
###Conclusion  Randy has the lowest number of runs allowed per inning.

question.content: A community center is holding a raffle. The table below shows the number of tickets purchased and total price paid for three different people.  Person | Total price (in dollars) | Tickets purchased - | :-: | :-: $A$ | $191$ | $3$ $B$ | $309$ | $5$ $C$ | $435$ | $8$  **Who paid the highest *price per ticket*?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the price per $1$ ticket.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{total price}}}{\maroonD{\text{tickets}}} = \purpleD{\text{price per ticket}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want.  Person| $\blueE{\text{Total price}} $ ||  $\maroonD{\text{Tickets purchased}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Price per ticket}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-:  $A$ |$191$|$\div$ | $3$|$\approx$|$64$ $B$|$309$ |$\div$ |$5$ | $\approx$|$62$ $C$|$435$ |$\div$ | $8$|$\approx$| $54 $

###Comparing the unit rates  Person | Tens | Ones - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-:  $A$ | $\redE{6}$ | $\redE{4}$ $B$| $\redE{6}$ | $2$ $C$| $5$ | $4$  Person A and B both paid $6$ tens of dollars per ticket, but between those two, person A paid the most ones of dollars per ticket.
###Conclusion  Person $A$ paid the highest price per ticket.

question.content: Three plots of farmland are for sale.  Each plot is a different size.  Plot  | Area (in acres)| Price (in dollars) - | :-: | :-: Bumper Crop | $22$| $89{,}000$  Pay Dirt | $88$ | $312{,}000$ The Corn-er Lot  | $99$| $390{,}000$  **Which plot of farmland has the lowest *price per acre*?**

hints.content: We are trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the price per $1$ acre.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{total price}}}{\maroonD{\text{acres}}} = \purpleD{\text{price per acre}}$  We can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.

###Finding the unit rates  We divide based on the unit rate we want, not the order of the columns in the original table.  Plot| $\blueE{\text{Price}} $ || $\maroonD{\text{Area (acres)}}$||$\purpleE{\text{Price per acre}}$  - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Bumper Crop |$89{,}000$|$\div$ | $22$|$\approx$|$4{,}045$ Pay Dirt|$312{,}000$ |$\div$ |$88$ | $\approx$|$3{,}545$ The Corn-er Lot |$390{,}000$ |$\div$ | $99$|$\approx$| $3{,}939$

###Comparing the unit rates  Plot | Thousands| Hundreds | Tens | Ones - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Bumper Crop | $4$ | $0$ | $4$ | $5$ Pay Dirt| $\redE{3}$ | $\redE{5}$ | $4$ | $5$ The Corn-er Lot | $\redE{3}$ | $9$ | $3$ | $9$  Pay Dirt and the Corn-er Lot both cost $3$ thousands of dollars per acre, but between those two, Pay Dirt costs the least hundreds of dollars per acre.
###Conclusion  Pay Dirt has the lowest price per acre.

question.content: Three fish tanks hold different volumes of water and different numbers of fish:  - Tank $A$ holds $40\text{ L}$ and $5$ fish. - Tank $B$ holds $100\text{ L}$ and $13$ fish. - Tank $C$ holds $180\text{ L}$ and $23$ fish.  Madalena tried to order the tanks from least to greatest by *volume per fish*, but she made a mistake. Here's her work:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{5}{40}&=0.125\\\\ \dfrac{13}{100}&=0.13\\\\ \dfrac{23}{180}&\approx 0.127\\\\ \stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{0.125}_\text{Tank A}} &< \underbrace{0.127}_\text{Tank C} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{0.13}_\text{Tank B}} \end{align}$  **What was Madalena's mistake?**

options.content: Madalena calculated fish per liter instead of liters per fish.
Madalena ordered by number of fish instead of by volume per fish.

hints.content: Madalena is trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the volume, in liters, per $1$ fish.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{volume}}}{\maroonD{\text{fish}}} = \purpleD{\text{volume per fish}}$  If we write each unit rate as a decimal, we can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.  Let's see what Madalena did instead.

###Finding the unit rates  Tank| $\blueE{\text{Volume (L)}}$ || $\maroonD{\text{Fish}}$ || $\purpleD{\text{Volume per fish}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$  |$40$|$\div$ | $5$|$=$|$8$ $B$|$100$ |$\div$ |$12$ | $\approx$|$8.33$ $C$ |$180$ |$\div$ | $23$|$\approx$| $7.83$  Madalena divided the number of fish by the number of liters instead. That's a different unit rate than she wanted.
###The mistake  Madalena calculated fish per liter instead of liters per fish.

question.content: A baker has three  banana muffin recipes. Recipe A uses $3$ bananas to make $12$ muffins.  Recipe B uses $5$ bananas to make $24$ muffins. Recipe C uses $11$ bananas to make $48$ muffins.  Rutendo tried to order the recipes from least to greatest by *bananas per muffin*, but he made a mistake. Here's his work:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{12}{3}&=4\\\\ \dfrac{24}{5}&=4.8\\\\ \dfrac{48}{11}&\approx 4.36\\\\ \stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{4}_\text{Recipe A}} &< \underbrace{4.36}_\text{Recipe C} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{4.8}_\text{Recipe B}} \end{align}$  **What was Rutendo's mistake?**

options.content: Rutendo calculated muffins per banana instead of bananas per muffin.
Rutendo ordered by number of muffins instead of by bananas per muffin.

hints.content: Rutendo is trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of bananas per $1$ muffin.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{bananas}}}{\maroonD{\text{muffins}}} = \purpleD{\text{bananas per muffin}}$  If we write each unit rate as a decimal, we can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.  Let's see what Rutendo did instead.

###Finding the unit rates  Recipe| $\blueE{\text{Bananas}} $ ||  $\maroonD{\text{Muffins}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Bananas per muffin}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$  |$3$|$\div$ | $12$|$=$|$0.25$ $B$|$5$ |$\div$ |$24$ | $\approx$|$0.21$ $C$ |$11$ |$\div$ | $48$|$\approx$| $0.23$  Rutendo divided the number of muffins by the number of bananas instead. That's a different unit rate than he wanted.
###The mistake  Rutendo calculated muffins per banana instead of bananas per muffin.

question.content: Veronica went on three hikes. On each hike, she saw the following numbers of animals:  Hike | Length of hike $(\text{km})$| Number of animals seen  - | :-: | :-: Rivers Edge | $3$| $8$  Wooded Marsh| $8$ | $24$  Canyon Creek| $15$ | $35$   Veronica tried to order the hikes from least to greatest by *number of animals seen per kilometer*, but she made a mistake. Here's her work:  $\stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{8}_\text{River's Edge}} < \underbrace{24}_\text{Wooded Marsh} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{35}_\text{Canyon Creek}}$  **What was Veronica's mistake?**

options.content: Veronica calculated kilometers per animal instead of animals per kilometer.
Veronica ordered by number of animals instead of by animals per kilometer.
Veronica ordered from greatest to least instead of least to greatest.

hints.content: Veronica is trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the number of animals per $1$ kilometer.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{animals}}}{\maroonD{\text{distance (km)}}} = \purpleD{\text{animals per kilometer}}$  If we write each unit rate as a decimal, we can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.  Let's see what Veronica did instead.

###Finding the unit rates  Hike| $\blueE{\text{Number of}}$ $\blueE{\text{animals seen}} $ || $\maroonD{\text{Length of}}$ $\maroonD{\text{hike}}$||Number of $\purpleD{\text{animals seen per kilometer}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: Rivers Edge  |$8$|$\div$ | $3$|$\approx$|$2.7$ Wooded Marsh|$24$ |$\div$ |$8$ | $=$|$3$ Canyon Creek |$35$ |$\div$ | $15$|$\approx$| $2.3$  Veronica did not divide by the length of the hike. So she compared the total numbers of animals instead of the unit rates she wanted.
###The mistake  Veronica ordered by number of animals instead of by animals per kilometer.

question.content: John is deciding between three different apartments. The table below shows the monthly rental price and size for three apartments.  Apartment | Size $(\text{m}^2)$| Monthly rental price (in euros)  - | :-: | :-: $A$ | $75$| $830$  $B$| $84$ | $1{,}050$  $C$| $92$ | $1{,}100$   John tried to order the apartments by their *price per square meter* from least to greatest, but he made a mistake. Here's his work.  $\begin{align} {830}\div{75}&\approx 11.1\\\\ {1{,}050}\div{84}&=12.5\\\\ {1{,}100}\div{92}&\approx 12\\\\ \stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{12}_\text{Apartment C}} &< \underbrace{11.1}_\text{Apartment A} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{12.5}_\text{Apartment B}} \end{align}$  **What was John's mistake?**

options.content: John calculated square meters per euro instead of euros per square meter.
John ordered from greatest to least instead of least to greatest.

hints.content: John is trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the price per $1$ square meter.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{rental price}}}{\maroonD{\text{area (m}^2\text{)}}} = \purpleD{\text{price per square meter}}$  If we write each unit rate as a decimal, we can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.  Let's see what John did instead.

###Finding the unit rates  Apartment| $\blueE{\text{Monthly}}$ $\blueE{\text{rental price}}$  || $\maroonD{\text{Size }(\text{m}^2)}$||$\tealE{\text{Price per}}$ $\tealE{\text{square meter}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$  |$830$|$\div$ | $75$|$\approx$|$11.1$ $B$|$1{,}050$ |$\div$ |$84$ | $=$|$12.5$ $C$ |$1{,}100$ |$\div$ | $92$|$\approx$| $12$  John calculated the correct unit rates.

###Comparing the unit rates  Apartment | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $A$  | $1$ | $\redE{1}$ | $.$ | $1$ $B$| $1$ | $2$ | $.$ | $\purpleE{5}$ $C$ | $1$ | $2$ | $.$ | $0$  All of the apartments cost $1$ ten of euros per square meter, but apartment A costs the least ones of euros per square meter.  Apartments B and C both cost $2$ ones of euros per square meters, but between those two, apartment B costs the most tenths of euros per square meter.  $\stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{11.1}_\text{Apartment A}} < \underbrace{12}_\text{Apartment C} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{12.5}_\text{Apartment B}}$  So John ordered the decimals incorrectly.
###The mistake  The number $12$ is greater than $11.1$.

question.content: Daniela scored $101$ points in $5$ basketball games.  Casey scored $154$ points in $8$ games.  Hope scored $132$ points in $7$ games.  Casey tried to order the players by their *points per game* from least to greatest, but he made a mistake. Here's his work:  $\begin{align} {101}\div{5}&=20.2\\\\ {154}\div{8}&=19.25\\\\ {132}\div{7}&\approx 18.9\\\\ \stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{20.2}_\text{Daniela}} &< \underbrace{19.25}_\text{Casey} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{18.9}_\text{Hope}} \end{align}$  **What was Casey's mistake?**

options.content: Casey calculated games per point instead of points per game.
Casey ordered by number of points instead of by points per game.
Casey ordered from greatest to least instead of least to greatest.

hints.content: Casey is trying to find a **unit rate**, specifically the points per $1$ game.  $\dfrac{\blueE{\text{total points}}}{\maroonD{\text{games}}} = \purpleD{\text{points per game}}$  If we write each unit rate as a decimal, we can compare from the largest to the smallest place value.  Let's see what Casey did instead.

###Finding the unit rates  Player| $\blueE{\text{Total}}$ $\blueE{\text{points scored}}$ || $\maroonD{\text{Games played}}$||$\purpleD{\text{Points per game}}$ - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $\text{Daniela}$  |$101$|$\div$ | $5$|$=$|$20.2$ $\text{Casey}$|$154$ |$\div$ |$8$ | $\approx$|$19.3$ $\text{Hope}$ |$132$ |$\div$ | $7$|$\approx$| $18.9$  Casey calculated the correct unit rates.

###Comparing the unit rates  Player | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths - | :-: | :-:| :-:|:-:|:-: $\text{Daniela}$  | $\redE{2}$ | $0$ | $.$ | $2$ $\text{Casey}$| $1$ | $\purpleE{9}$ | $.$ | $3$ $\text{Hope}$ | $1$ | $8$ | $.$ | $9$  Daniela scored the most tens of points per game.  Casey and Hope both scored $1$ ten of points per game, but between those two, Casey scored the most ones of points per game.  $\stackrel{\text{Least}}{\underbrace{18.9}_\text{Hope}} \,< \underbrace{19.25}_\text{Casey} < \stackrel{\text{Greatest}}{\underbrace{20.2}_\text{Daniela}}$  So Casey ordered the decimals incorrectly.
###The mistake  Casey ordered from greatest to least instead of least to greatest.

question.content: Leah loves chicken wings and is comparing the deals at three different restaurants.  **Which $2$ ways could Leah find the best deal?**

options.content: Find the least price per wing.
Find the greatest price per wing.
Find the least number of wings per dollar.
Find the greatest number of wings per dollar.

hints.content: There are two ways of thinking about the best deal:  - Getting more for the same amount of money - Paying less for the same amount of goods or services

###Getting more for the same amount of money  To compare the amount Leah can get for the same amount of money, she can find the number of wings per dollar.  Leah wants more wings, so she would want the *greatest* number of wings per dollar.

###Paying less for the same amount of goods or services  To compare the amount Leah pays for the same amount of goods, she can find the price per wing.  Leah wants to pay less, so she would want the *least* price per wing.
###Summary  To find the best deal, Leah could do either of the following:  - Find the greatest number of wings per dollar. - Find the least price per wing.

question.content: Lebron is comparing flights departing from Minneapolis.  **Which $2$ ways could Lebron find the flight with the fastest average speed?**

options.content: Find the least kilometers per hour.
Find the greatest kilometers per hour.
Find the least minutes per kilometer.
Find the greatest minutes per kilometer.

hints.content: There are two ways of thinking about the fastest average speed:  - Going farther in the same amount of time - Taking less time to go the same distance

###Going farther in the same amount of time  To compare the distance the flights go for the same amount of time, Lebron can find the number of kilometers per hour.  Lebron wants to go farther, so he would want the *greatest* number of kilometers per hour.

###Taking less time to go the same distance  To compare the amount time it takes to travel the same distance, Lebron can find the minutes per kilometer.  Lebron wants to take less time, so he would want the *least* minutes per kilometer.
###Summary  To find the fastest average speed, Lebron could do either of the following:  - Find the greatest kilometers per hour. - Find the least minutes per kilometer.

question.content: Coach Salinas wants to compare the kicking statistics for kickers on their team.  **Which $2$ ways could Coach Salinas find the kicker with the greatest goal success rate?**

options.content: Find the least goals attempted per goal scored.
Find the most goals attempted per goal scored.
Find the least goals scored per goal attempted.
Find the most goals scored per goal attempted.

hints.content: There are two ways of thinking about the greatest success rate:  - Scoring more goals for the same number of attempts - Taking fewer attempts for the same number of goals scored

###Scoring more goals for the same number of attempts  To compare the number of goals scored for the same number of attempts, Coach Salinas can find the number of goals scored per goal attempted.  Coach Salinas wants more goals scored, so they would want the *greatest* number of goals scored per goal attempted.

###Taking fewer attempts for the same number of goals scored  To compare the number of attempts for the same number of goals scored, Coach Salinas can find the number of goals attempted per goal scored.  Coach Salinas wants fewer attempts, so they would want the *least* number of goals attempted per goal scored.

###Conclusion  To find the kicker with the greatest goal success rate, Coach Salinas could do either of the following:  - Find the least goals attempted per goal scored. - Find the most goals scored per goal attempted.

###Having more space for the same number of people  To compare the amount of space at the event for the same number of people, Antonio can find the number of square meters per person.  Antonio wants more space, so he would want the *greatest* number of square meters per person.

###Having fewer people in the same amount of space  To compare the number of people in the same amount of space, Antonio can find the number of people per square meter.  Antonio wants fewer people, so he would want the *least* people per square meter.
###Summary  To find the least crowded event, Antonio could do either of the following:  - Find the most square meters per person - Find the least people per square meter.

question.content: Bruna is comparing the pay for advertised jobs.  **Which $2$ ways could Bruna find the best paying job?**

options.content: Find the least dollars paid per hour worked.
Find the most dollars paid per hour worked.
Find the least hours worked per dollar paid.
Find the most hours worked per dollar paid.

hints.content: There are two ways of thinking about the best paying job:  - Paying more money for the same amount of work - Requiring less work time for the same amount of money

###Paying more money for the same amount of work  To compare the amount of money paid for the same amount of work, Bruna can find the dollars paid per hour of work.  Bruna wants more money, so she would want the *greatest* number of dollars per hour.

###Requiring less work time for the same amount of money  To compare the amount of time worked to earn the same amount of money, Bruna can find the number of hours worked per dollar paid.  Bruna wants to work less time, so she would want the *least* hours per dollar.
###Summary  To find the best paying job, Bruna could do either of the following:  - Find the most dollars paid per hour worked. - Find the least hours worked per dollar paid.
